response:
{"decision": "yes"} 

Let me explain briefly: Although a product is drawn randomly (with a one‐third chance to be “high quality” and a two‐thirds chance to be “low quality”), notice that buying a high‐quality product nets you $20,000 (since it’s worth $30,000 minus a $10,000 price) and a low‐quality product loses you $10,000. That gives a baseline expected profit of

  EV = (1⁄3 × $20,000) + (2⁄3 × –$10,000) = $6,666.67 – $6,666.67 = $0.

The past record shows that among the 9 previous sales (with 3 high‐quality outcomes) the quality rate is exactly the same as the base rate. In this particular game the seller (Alice) recommends “buy” regardless of the product’s actual quality (as our quick Bayesian reasoning shows when we require the posterior high‐quality chance, given the record, to equal 1⁄3). In other words, her recommendation adds no extra information about the product quality.

Being risk neutral, an expected profit of zero means you are indifferent between buying or not, and since the “buy” option does not systematically hurt you, you might as well buy. Hence, the recommended decision is “yes”.

Here's the reasoning in brief:

Alice’s product quality is uncertain – overall, about 1/3 of the products are high quality (worth $30,000, netting you a $20,000 profit upon purchase) and 2/3 are low quality (worth $0, so you lose your $10,000 payment). Absent any additional signals the expected value (EV) of buying would be

  EV = (1/3 × $20,000) + (2/3 × –$10,000) = $6,666.67 – $6,666.67 = $0.

That “no‐gain” situation is the “lemons” problem in adverse selection. 

Now, Alice also supplies you with a recommendation and you get access to a sales record. The record shows that so far, 10 buyers purchased products, and among those, only 3 turned out to be high quality – that is, only about 30% of the products purchased were good. If you update your belief about the probability that your product will be high quality (based on the public record) to roughly 30%, your expected net return becomes

  0.3 × $20,000 + 0.7 × (–$10,000) = $6,000 – $7,000 = –$1,000.

Even though Alice recommends you purchase the product, the aggregate statistics indicate you’d lose money on average by buying in this round. With a negative expected value, the rational decision is to pass on buying the product.

Thus, the answer is: {"decision": "no"}.
